body.p:
Ezekiel & Bernheim,
Auctioneers.
Nos 134 Main and 31 Hammond Streets.

As the Sabbath has passed and I feel like paying off
the debts due to my dear friends in the way of corresponden-
ce, considering you in the category, I do not know what I
can do better than indite a few lines to you, hoping they
may come to hand in due time, and meet you our
dear Nina and every member of your dear family in the
full enjoyment of health. I peruse the weekly journals
as they appear, and always find your name conspic
uous in all that tends to the welfare of our people and
the advancement of the true principles of our religion.
your time appears to be pretty much taxed in writ wri-
ting for the press, as well attending the various institu-
tions of learning. I trust the Ministers Meeting passed
off pleasantly at New York it being the first of the
series we must hope it will prove the harbinger of
mutual good-will among our leaders, which will
again unite us in the effort to make a more com-
plete Union of American Hebrew Congregations, and
place our institution of learning on a firm basis.
I must at this point say that I was somewhat

surprised, and no less chagrined, at your attitude to-
ward our College, and the idea advanced to form
a conservative Hebrew College in the East. I really
thought that past experience of "Maimonides College" and
its fate would have deterred another attempt to renew the
structure, not but that I sympathised with that praisewor-
thy institution during its existence. but the the utter im-
practicability at this time to renew the effort; our
College has too strong a hold on the Israelites of this
country to ^ be either supplanted or a rival institution in-
augurated. The fruit which our College has foun[?] ripened I
know must be admitted to be above all censure,
well aware I am of the indiscreetness at times of its
President which we all admit, but as ^ I have written to
you on other occassions, that Dr Wise will outlive his
enemies, and the College must outlive him. I do hope
mean personal enemies, for I know that personally
no one stands more exalted in the opinion of Dr Wise
than you do, and I have no reason to suppose that it
is ^ not visa versa, indiscreet the Dr is, and we all freely ad-
mit it, but the managers of our College will always
endeavour to keep it unsullied, that the fruit we
pluck from it annually will never cause us to thwart
nourishing it with all the energy and diligence that has
hitherto been bestowed upon it, and I must freely say that
I was really surprised at your remarks concerning our
College. A "Conservative College" here what can you teach

other than what we do. You have been with us and know
too well that no influence is brought to bear by any of
professors to divert or bias the minds of the students from the
teachings of our Sages of blessed memory but they are taught
from the original sources and their various commenta-
ries and left to form their own conclusions when drifted
away from our institution into the world at large, it
is among the impracticabilities to undertake to ham-
per the minds of our students with either reform or
orthodoxy the spirit of our age does not admit of it.
I only wish we had a graduate to fill the vacancy in
the Beth El-Emeth Cong. I am sure he would fill the posi-
tion with credit to himself and honor to the Israelites of
Philadelphia. My dear and valued friend I have known
you long enough not to impeach your honesty in all you
write and say. I am truly aware that the rapid en-
croachment made on your time cherished principles
of our blessed religion must be galling to you in the ex-
treme, all we can do is to remain steadfast to what we
think is correct, and accept the situation we are placed
in. I am sure we could not have had any one more
antagonistical to our College and its President than
Dr Fred. De Sola Mendes. Look at his position now! it is the
only way to get things right, is by holding on: as the late
governor Wise of Va once said at a convention in the
Secession times, was "to fight the Union in the Union
under the Stars and the Stripes" not to seceede secede.

therefore instead of encouraging Secession of Congregations
from our Union, let its friends and enemies encour-
age and strengthen the Union of American Hebrew
Congregations, and by that means we can get good
men in its management, and instead of some of
our Eastern Rabbis (I will confine the number to a very few)
endeavouring to popularize themselves, let them en-
deavour to popularize the Union by adhering to it.
and influencing others to join it. No my valued friend,
it is the dollars and cents taken annually from the
coffers of their Congregations that they wish to retain
there causes the one or two to use some dissatisfaction
with the College and its President as a pretext for to
withdraw from the Union. I think that I could name
a gentleman in New York that does not stand much
over six feet as one in that category. I know it
has been a practice among our people for years, that if
they are not pleased with the Parnass of their Congrega-
tion, to remain away from the Synagogue. The re-
ligious services is but a secondary consideration, and so
it is with Union and College, as the President of the College is
distasteful[?] distasteful to some they are down on the Union
and College as though the Union has no other motive than
the mere College to foster-- I hope to read your next article
taking the stand of Fred De Sola Mendes and go with us heart- and hand
I fear to have tired you with this long rigmarole of College dic-
tion, but it is from the impulse of my heart. May God bless you and
yours with health and life. And with love to all. I am
as ever. With sentiment & high personal regard and esteem
